title: Add time module to API
body: Use the `TZ` environment variable in the `list` command to display the local date and time in the same way as the `date` command and move the shared logic to a `time` module in the API.

title: Extend lisp language
body:
- [x] Add `mapcar` builtin (aliased to `map`)
- [x] Add `ensure_length_eq` and `ensure_length_gt` macros to rust code to simplify eval
- [x] Add `div`, `mod`, and `exp` math functions (aliased to `/`, `%`, and `^`)
- [x] Rewrite `eq` function to work on lists
- [x] Rewrite `atom` function
- [x] Add `load` function to load lisp files
- [x] Add `/ini/lisp/core.lsp` with more primitives
- [x] Rename `read-file` to `read`

title: Rewrite Lisp parser with Nom
body:
- [x] Rewrite parser with [Nom](https://github.com/Geal/nom)
- [x] Refactor eval
- [x] Add strings

title: Add pci command and switch IDE controllers to compatible mode
Fix editor cursor after status change
Fix autocomplete bug
body: Using `append` instead of `extend` move the elements instead of cloning them, producing a bug in the autocomplete code.

title: Enable asm_sym feature
body:
Fix `error[E0658]: sym operands for inline assembly are unstable` compilation error.

See https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/72016

title: Add process table and exit syscall
body:
Improve process structure and use a table to save them.

This will allow use to save the registers of a process before spawning a new one so we can switch back to it later.

title: Improve UTF-8 support
body:
MOROS started with only ASCII but it supports AZERTY keyboards that have accented keys that break the assumption that a character in a string takes only one byte. This PR change the console IO, the prompt, and the editor to work on character vectors (equivalent to UTF-32) instead of strings (UTF-8).

It is good enough for Latin languages but more work is needed to fully support UTF-8. We'll also need to read the unicode table at the end of PCF fonts and improve rendering.

title: Add calc command
body: Add a calculator using [nom](https://github.com/Geal/nom) from https://github.com/balajisivaraman/basic_calculator_rs

title: Add shell redirections
body:
The initial plan for MOROS Shell was to emulate redirections with pipes and `read` or `write` commands like `print hello -> write /tmp/test` that can be shortened to `p hello > w /tmp/test` where `>` is the equivalent of `|` for Unix shells.

Pipes are not yet implemented but with a `DUP` syscall and the file handle table it's easy to implement redirections like `print hello => /tmp/test` where `=>` is the same than `>` for Unix shells.

title: Add website
body:
Add a static website with a simple landing page hosted at [moros.cc](http://moros.cc).

The server allow both HTTP and HTTPS to be browsable from inside MOROS so the website can be used in request examples.

title: Add rust binaries support
body: This is a continuation of #248 and fix some issues with the stack that allow us to run very small rust programs. Next step will be to dynamically allocate the correct amount of code memory and stack.

title: Enable array_map feature
body: This was required for #253

title: Remove array-macro dependency
body:
Hello, I'm a maintainer of `array-macro` crate.

Code that was using `array_macro::array!` used it incorrectly causing a subtle issue. In 2.0.0 the behaviour of `array` macro did change to clone values to match the behavior of standard library's [`vec! macro`](https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/std/macro.vec.html).

In the code that used this macro it was used for objects of `PhysBuf` type.

```rust
#[derive(Clone)]
pub struct PhysBuf {
    buf: Arc<Mutex<Vec<u8>>>,
}
```

For `Arc` objects cloning doesn't create a new object, rather it shares a reference causing a subtle issue where all elements of `rx_buffers` shared the exact same buffer, which I don't think you have intended.

Standard library now contains `array::map` which can replace `array_macro::array!` in most situations. It may be a good idea to use that, considering amount of people that look at standard library's code is greater than number of people that look at `array_macro` (which is just me).

title: Add dynamical disk information
body:
- [x] Add `SuperBlock` struct
- [x] Add `LinkedBlock` struct
- [x] Add `Drive` struct
- [x] Store total and allocated block count in super block
- [x] Dynamically allocate the fs based on disk size or memory size
- [x] Dynamically allocate the heap based on memory size
- [x] Use the whole block for bitmap blocks
- [x] Remove hardcoded bitmap and data area and size
- [ ] Add dynamical offset to superblock area

title: Add ELF loader
body:
This PR will bring us closer to be being able to run rust binaries, but some issues are still remaining. For now we'll be able to run ELF binaries produced in the following way:

```
nasm dsk/src/bin/hello.s -o /tmp/hello.o -f elf64
ld -o dsk/bin/hello /tmp/hello.o -Ttext=100 -Tdata=200
```

Instead of raw binaries produced like so:

```
nasm dsk/src/bin/hello.s -o /tmp/hello -f bin
```

title: Add basic userspace
body:
This PR is an experiment into implementing a userspace mode.

I started from this article: https://nfil.dev/kernel/rust/coding/rust-kernel-to-userspace-and-back/
And the OSDev wiki as usual: https://wiki.osdev.org/Getting_to_Ring_3
Then I found this gem: https://github.com/WartaPoirier-corp/ananos/blob/dev/docs/notes/context-switch.md
Along with the associated code in the repo that is a perfect starting point to get an idea of how to get something working.
